education.title: Understanding BMI
education.content1: Body Mass Index (BMI) is a simple measure using height and weight to estimate body fat. While not perfect, it's a useful screening tool for weight categories.
education.content2: BMI doesn't account for muscle mass, bone density, or fat distribution. Athletes may have high BMI despite low body fat. Use it as one of many health indicators.

tip1.title: BMI is a Screening Tool
tip1.description: It's not a diagnostic tool. Consult healthcare providers for complete assessment.

tip2.title: Consider Other Metrics
tip2.description: Waist circumference and body fat percentage provide additional insights.

tip3.title: Focus on Overall Health
tip3.description: Diet, exercise, and mental health matter as much as weight.

tip4.title: Track Progress Over Time
tip4.description: Single measurements matter less than trends.

faq.question: How accurate is BMI?
faq.answer: BMI is a useful screening tool but has limitations. It may overestimate body fat in athletes and underestimate it in older adults who have lost muscle mass.

faq.question: What's a healthy BMI?
faq.answer: A BMI between 18.5 and 24.9 is considered healthy for most adults. However, optimal weight can vary based on age, gender, and body composition.

faq.question: Should I only rely on BMI?
faq.answer: No. BMI should be one of several health indicators. Consider waist circumference, body fat percentage, blood pressure, and cholesterol levels too.
